data.title: In Belgium, memories of another tragic princess
authors: Paul Ames, Associated Press , New Bedford Standard-Times

data.text:
She was young, beautiful, adored by her people and mother of the future king. Then one August day, a car crash cut her life short and plunged the nation into an unprecedented wave of grief.

For Belgians, the death of 36-year-old Princess Diana evokes poignant memories of their own princess -- Astrid, who came from Sweden to marry the heir to the Belgian throne in 1926.

Like Diana, Astrid acquired a fairy-tale aura. She was Belgium's "Queen of smiles." Like Diana, she was loved for her beauty, her charitable works and the casual, relaxed style she brought to a stuffy court.

And like Diana, she died in a car crash before reaching the prime of life, leaving young children behind.

Diana's death Sunday came 62 years almost to the day when King Leopold III lost control of his Packard 120 on a lakeside road in Switzerland. On Aug. 29, 1935, the car plunged off the road, killing his 29-year-old wife instantly.

In a curious coincidence, Diana's car crashed a few yards from the Place Reine Astrid, the Paris square named for the Belgian queen.

Unlike Diana, Astrid became queen. Her two sons became kings of Belgium.

The current monarch, Albert, was only 13 months old when Astrid died. His elder brother Boudouin, who was 4 years old when their mother died, ruled from 1951 until his death in 1993. Their older sister Josephine-Charlotte is Grand-Duchess of Luxembourg.

Astrid acquired near-mythical status in Belgium.

"She is still referred to with extraordinary nostalgia," historian Pierre Wyvekens wrote in 1992. "Her life might have made a wonderful story if only it had not been tragically cut short in its first chapter."

Today there are no fewer than 16 streets and squares in Brussels that bear her name.

Astrid, nicknamed "the swan of the north" for her graceful beauty, outshone her husband in the public's affections almost from the moment she arrived from Sweden.

After her death, many Belgians blamed Leopold for the crash. He was driving fast on the twisting road beside the Vierwaldstaeter Lake and escaped with minor injuries after the car spun off the road.

He remarried in 1941 when Belgium was under Nazi occupation. He had three children with his new wife Princess Lilian.

In 1944, accusations he collaborated with the Nazis forced Leopold into exile. He returned in 1950, but a storm of protests brought Belgium to the brink of civil war and forced him to abdicate the following year. Leopold died in 1983 at age 81.

Photo by The Associated Press

Belgium's Queen Astrid died at the age of 29 in a 1935 car crash in Switzerland, leaving her young children motherless. Like Princess Diana, Belgium's "Queen of smiles" had acquired a fairy-tale aura.
